titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Cocheu family papers 1977.141
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Matthew Gorham (2011); Updated by John Zarrillo (2014)
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2014-09-30T15:05-0400

physdesc.extent: in two bound volumes in one folder

did.abstract: Included in the papers are two scrapbooks that include news clippings, poems, a marriage certificate, photographs, obituaries, prayers, programs, and correspondence, dated 1863 to 1959.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Cocheu family were long time residents of the Williamsburg neighborhood of Brooklyn. Theodore Cocheu married Catherine Benson in 1867. Their son Frank Cocheu (1871-1959) was a Major General in the United States Army.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Cocheu family papers measure 0.3 linear feet and span the period 1863 to 1959. Included in the papers are two scrapbooks that include news clippings, poems, a marriage certificate, photographs, obituaries, prayers, programs, and correspondence, dated 1863 to 1959. One scrapbook consists of clippings of Frank Cocheu and his military activities during the First World War. The second scrapbook consists of materials relating to Theodore and Catherine Cocheu. There is also a folder of miscellaneous items including four photographs of the Cocheu and Benson families, correspondence to and from Frank Cocheu, biographical materials on Frank Cocheu, and images related to the U.S. Navy and naval warfare.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Cocheu family papers, 1977.141, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.
